questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because she wants to lose weight for her upcoming wedding. In the past 6 months, she has tried several diets without success and feels like she has “lost control” over her eating habits. She says, “At least twice per week, I just load up on junk food, even when I am not even feeling hungry. I feel so disgusted with myself because I am just not able to stop.” Afterward, she typically feels uncomfortably full and lies in bed watching television until her stomach feels better. She is embarrassed about her behavior and avoids eating with her partner because she does not want him to find out. She is concerned that she will look “hideous” on her wedding day and tries to hide her body by wearing oversized clothes. Medical history is remarkable for social anxiety disorder, for which she received cognitive behavioral therapy 5 years ago. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 65.8 kg (145 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she has a sad affect and repeatedly expresses guilt about her lack of self-control. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient is concerned about her physical appearance and worried about gaining weight, her binge eating behavior is not consistent with body dysmorphic disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Fear of gaining weight and body image disturbance are features of anorexia nervosa, which can include episodes of binge eating. However, this patient does not intentionally restrict energy intake, which is required for an anorexia nervosa diagnosis. Moreover, patients with anorexia nervosa are underweight (i.e., BMI < 18.5).

C) INCORRECT:

Adjustment disorder is a maladaptive response that occurs within three months of a stressor and is characterized by either a disproportionate level of distress or impaired functioning that cannot be explained by a different mental disorder. Although this patient is experiencing stress because of her upcoming wedding and has signs of impaired functioning (not eating with her husband, lack of control over eating habits), her symptoms can be explained by a different mental disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Recurrent binge eating episodes are a feature of bulimia nervosa, which can manifest in patients with a normal BMI. However, this patient has no purging behaviors (e.g., vomiting, laxative misuse, excessive exercise), which rules out bulimia nervosa.

E) CORRECT:

Binge eating disorder manifests with binge eating episodes at least once a week for over three months, characterized by excessive consumption of food within a given period and a lack of control over eating. Episodes of binge eating are associated with three or more of the following: eating faster than normal, eating until uncomfortably full, eating when not hungry, significant distress, and negative emotions (e.g., embarrassment, disgust, depression, guilt). This disorder has no purging behavior, which is the main difference from bulimia nervosa. Individuals with binge eating disorder can have a BMI that is elevated or within the normal range, and women are more commonly affected. Therapy consists of nutritional management in combination with psychotherapy (e.g., CBT) or pharmacotherapy (e.g., SSRIs).
questions.hint: This patient has the most common eating disorder among adults in the US.
